introduction: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
text:
• In 1960, Jane Goodall traveled to Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania to study chimpanzees.
• She observed that chimpanzees made and used tools, an ability once thought unique to humans.
• Goodall’s research challenged long-held beliefs about the gap between humans and other primates.
• She worked with Louis Leakey, who encouraged her to document her groundbreaking observations.
• Over decades, Goodall became a leader in conservation and animal welfare efforts.
question: The student wants to emphasize how Jane Goodall’s discoveries redefined the boundary between humans and other primates. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?
A: Jane Goodall traveled to Tanzania in 1960, documenting her observations under the guidance of Louis Leakey.
B: By revealing that chimpanzees made and used tools, Jane Goodall overturned the notion that only humans possessed this skill.
C: Goodall became a prominent advocate for conservation after studying chimpanzees in Gombe Stream National Park.
D: Research in Gombe Stream National Park demonstrated chimpanzees’ complex behaviors.
explanation: Choice B highlights how Goodall’s revelation about chimpanzee tool use specifically blurred the distinction between human and primate capabilities.
